title: Stacey Solomon's parents were ‘disappointed’ in teenage pregnancy
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Stacey Solomon has spoken about how her parents were ‘disappointed’ in her after they found out she was pregnant with her first child as a teenager.

The Loose Woman panellist found out she was pregnant with son Zachary when she was just seventeen and when her parents first found out they were ‘upset’ and ‘hurt and disappointed’.

Stacey explained how first finding out she was pregnant with her boyfriend at the time left her in ‘utter turmoil’ as she wasn’t sure what to do.

In the end the experience taught her to take responsibility for her own decisions.

Speaking on the show about her decision to become a parent, she said: ‘There were times when I considered not going down that route because I was so young and my boyfriend at the time was so young.

‘It was a really tough decision to make.

‘I always remember my parents wouldn’t give me any input [into the decision] whatsoever.’

Stacey had her third baby Rex earlier this year (Picture: Andy Barnes / BACKGRID)

‘Even though they were really upset with me, and hurt and disappointed, they never told me whether I should go ahead and have the baby or not have the baby, which at the time was absolute turmoil because all I wanted was for my mum and dad to tell me what to do,’ she added.

‘I just felt like I couldn’t make such a big decision on my own, I really needed them.

‘But looking back, in hindsight, it was the best thing they could have ever done because I made that decision on my own and I took responsibility for it.’

Stacey is also mum to six-year-old Leighton, with her former fiancé Aaron Barnham, and gave birth to her third child Rex, with partner Joe Swash, earlier this year and has spoken about how having multiple parents in the family can sometimes be tricky.

‘Life is so much more complicated with kids from different dads, for sure,’ she told Closer.

‘There are definitely dynamics I’ve had to work around, and it’s not as straightforward as a conventional family.

‘But it’s wonderful at the same time – I’m so glad I moved forward from those relationships because it wouldn’t have been right to stay in them.’
